title: 112_hr4234
content: The "Grazing Improvement Act of 2012" amends the Federal Land Policy and Management Act of 1976 to extend grazing permits and leases from 10 to 20 years. It also includes provisions for the completion of environmental analysis before issuing permits or leases. Additionally, the Act addresses the renewal, transfer, and reissuance of grazing permits and leases. The "Grazing Improvement Act of 2012" extends grazing permits and leases from 10 to 20 years. It defines current grazing management and the Secretary concerned. Grazing permits or leases issued by the Secretary of the Interior or Agriculture must be renewed or reissued under specific sections. The grazing permit or lease issued by the Secretary of the Interior or Agriculture must be renewed or reissued under specific sections, with terms and conditions continuing until processing is completed by the Secretary concerned. The Secretary concerned must renew or reissue a grazing permit or lease until processing is completed, with the option to cancel, suspend, or modify it in accordance with the law. After processing, the permit or lease can be renewed or reissued for a term of 20 years. The renewal, reissuance, or transfer may be exempt from environmental assessment requirements at the discretion of the Secretary concerned. The Secretary concerned may categorically exclude the renewal, reissuance, or transfer of a grazing permit from environmental assessment requirements if it continues current management, meets objectives, or aligns with department policies. The priority and timing for completing environmental analyses will be determined at the Secretary's discretion. The Department of the Interior or Agriculture will decide on completing environmental analyses for grazing allotments based on significance and funding availability. NEPA exemptions include livestock authorizations and grazing preference transfers. Sec. 405 addresses the renewal, transfer, and reissuance of grazing permits and leases.
